title: Laser-Cut Box
description: I had to design an open box using Autodesk Fusion 360 and laser-cut that design on a sheet of cardboard to eventually end up with a physical box.

timeline.heading: Design
timeline.description: I designed the box using Autodesk Fusion 360. I started with a simple box by extruding a rectangular sketch. Then, I created the long and short walls by creating new sketches and extruding them. Throughout the process, I used tools I hadn't used before, like constraints, construction lines, and the mirror tool, to create the walls. After I finished, I verified that the dimensions of the box were correct and exported the project as a PDF for the laser cutter.

timeline.heading: Cutting
timeline.description: I uploaded the PDF I exported to the laser cutter and configured the settings of the cutter. After that, I placed the cardboard sheet in the cutter and started it. I tried running the cutter a few times to ensure the cutter cut through the sheet. I took it out and separated the box pieces from the sheet.

timeline.heading: Final Product
timeline.description: I took all the pieces and assembled them to form a box, shown right. Overall, the box fit well and held together decently on its own. After cutting, I noticed that the laser cutter didn't fully cut through the sheet; it only went most of the way through. Also, there was a lot of ash and burn marks on the edges of the box. I think next time, I could increase the frequency of the laser cutter from 500 to 2000 to decrease the time spent cutting and get a deeper cut. I learned a lot more about Fusion 360 in this project, like constraint and mirroring tools to draw sketches, as well as operating laser cutters and I think this knowledge could be useful when I need to cut material into a 3D structure in a future project.
